quoteFirst: It was not considered ominous when, in 1838, the Admiralty had requested proposals for a steam service to America. This demand was prompted by the voyages of the Sirius and Great Western, wooden-hulled sidewheelers which thrashed along at ten knots' speed and crossed the Atlantic in
quoteLast: teen days. This was a much faster rate than the average time of the Yankee packets, but America was unperturbed and showed no interest in steam. In 1839 the British Government awarded an Atlantic mail contract, with an annual subsidy of $425,000 to Samuel Cunard and his associates, and thereby created the most famous of the Atlantic steamship companies.
title: The Old Merchant Marine: A Chronicle of American Ships and Sailors
author: Paine, Ralph Delahaye, 1871-1925

quoteFirst: Neither did Dig at all resemble such an unfortunate animal for the three years, that is to say, from
quoteLast: teen, that he passed at his father's humble trade. Every leisure season was spent in literature; and he had not only read some hundreds of volumes by the time that he had reached the age of seventeen, but he had made some attempts at original composition that were by no means contemptible.
title: Wise Saws and Modern Instances, Volume 2 (of 2)
author: Cooper, Thomas, 1805-1892

quoteFirst: The average size of the regular collier has long been about 230 tons register, with a capacity of from
quoteLast: teen keels of coals;[428] and they were chiefly employed in the trade between the northern coal ports and London, although a considerable number of them were required to supply the wants of the outports (especially before the introduction of railways), and to these many of them still trade as well as to London.
title: History of merchant shipping and ancient commerce, Volume 2 (of 4)

quoteFirst: It was generally supposed that the end of it had been discovered, but we proved it to be still unknown; though, from the information I received, we proceeded into it further than any others, and our entrance into the third newly discovered chambers, or cave, was only prevented by a descent of fourteen feet. This great and astonishing work of God is divided into various apartments, from
quoteLast: ty feet in length, and eight to one hundred in breadth. By measurement, I found that we had proceeded about nine hundred feet into the cavern of a mountain, of five hundred feet in perpendicular height; the grotto is about two hundred feet above the level of the river running by the hill.
title: The Book of Curiosities
author: Platts, John, 1775-1837

title: Gold
author: White, Stewart Edward, 1873-1946; Fogarty, Thomas, 1873-1938 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: , many small islands, rocks, and shoals, lying between us and the main, and many of a larger extent without us. Our soundings till near noon were from
quoteLast: teen fathom, when the boat made the signal for meeting with shoal water. Upon this we hauled close upon a wind to the eastward, but suddenly fell into three fathom and a quarter: we immediately dropped an anchor, which brought the ship up with all her sails standing.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. II. Being the Second of the First Voyage
